bestBHT.bht: Jesus' healing of the blind and lame in the temple serves as a powerful confirmation of his teachings. The blind and lame, who witnessed these miracles, provide compelling evidence of his divine authority as the Messiah. The transformation of the temple from a den of robbers to a house of prayer and mercy highlights Jesus' emphasis on compassion and kindness. This profound act demonstrates the inseparable connection between faith and action, reinforcing the doctrine he preached.

John Calvin: He therefore cured the blind and lame in the temple, in order to proclaim that the rights and honor of Messiah truly belonged to him; for by these marks the prophets describe him.

We ought indeed to believe that the lame and blind, who were cured, were witnesses of the divine power of Christ, as if God, by his voice from heaven, approved what had been proclaimed by the multitude.
It is not every one of the people who is called to imitate this action of Christ lest he inconsiderately raise himself to the throne of the Messiah.
Philip Schaff: Matthew 21:14. Blind and lame. ‘A house of prayer’ becomes a house of mercy. The making it ‘a den of robbers’ was unmerciful.
John Gill: The blind could not come to him unless they were led, nor the lame, unless they were carried: the sense therefore is, they came, being brought to him.
He healed them...which miracles he wrought in confirmation of the doctrine he preached.
For all the other evangelists relate, that he taught in the temple.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Matthew 21:14, Jesus cures the blind and lame in the temple, demonstrating that he is the Messiah. By healing them, he confirms the validity of his teachings and proclaims his divine power. The blind and lame, witnesses to the miracles, show that the rights and honor of the Messiah truly belong to Jesus. This act of healing serves as a powerful declaration, reinforcing the doctrine that Jesus was preaching. His actions in the temple highlight the importance of mercy and compassion, transforming it from a den of robbers into a house of prayer and mercy.

By curing the blind and lame in the temple, Jesus both validates his teachings and proclaims his divine power as the Messiah. The blind and lame, witnesses to these miracles, testify to the authenticity of his role. In transforming the temple from a den of robbers into a house of prayer and mercy, Jesus emphasizes the importance of compassion and extends his message to include acts of kindness and healing. His actions in the temple serve as a powerful confirmation of the doctrine he preached.

Jesus demonstrated his messianic authority by healing the blind and lame in the temple. These miracles served as a validation of his teachings, showing the divine power that accompanied him. The blind and lame, witnessing these acts, became living testimonies to the truth of his message. By transforming the temple into a place of prayer and mercy, Jesus emphasized the importance of compassion and demonstrated that true worship involves acts of kindness and healing.

Jesus, in Matthew 21:14, showed his messianic authority by healing the blind and lame in the temple. These miracles validated his teachings and displayed his divine power. The blind and lame, as witnesses, testified to the truth of his message. By transforming the temple into a house of prayer and mercy, Jesus emphasized the significance of compassion. His actions confirmed the doctrine he preached, demonstrating the inseparable connection between faith and acts of kindness.

Jesus' healing of the blind and lame in the temple serves as a powerful confirmation of his teachings. The blind and lame, who witnessed these miracles, provide compelling evidence of his divine authority as the Messiah. The transformation of the temple from a den of robbers to a house of prayer and mercy highlights Jesus' emphasis on compassion and kindness. This profound act demonstrates the inseparable connection between faith and action, reinforcing the doctrine he preached.
